title: Cat. 11  Still Life with Geranium, 1906
publication_title: Matisse Paintings, Works on Paper, Sculpture, and Textiles at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Still Life with Geranium  
Collioure, summer 1906  
Oil on linen canvas; present size: 100.3 × 81.5 cm (39 1/2 × 32 1/8 in.); original size: 100 × 81 cm (39 3/8 × 31 7/8 in.)  
Signed: Henri-Matisse (lower left, in blue paint)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, Joseph Winterbotham Collection, 1932.1342

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">Henri Matisse painted Still Life with Geranium on a no. 40 portrait (figure) standard-size (100 × 73 cm) linen canvas, pre-primed with a warm-toned lead white ground. The painting appears to retain its original stretcher. Matisse first painted a rudimentary brush sketch of the basic composition in thin black outlines. He applied subtle warm glazes over the ground in the area of the compositional background. As a contrast to these tones, he used pale purple to indicate geranium leaves, then painted over them with varied greens using quick directional brushstrokes. The artist heavily worked the paint in the upper half using a layered technique, which belied the rapid brushwork that gives the upper portion of the composition the appearance of a sketch. Over the initial warm glazes, Matisse continued to adjust the color and the atmospheric light. He eliminated the darkly glazed penumbra of the top corners by lightening them with pronounced white scumbles, then added fluid blue strokes on top. In the background he worked back and forth between light and dark blues, producing an animated, shifting quality around the geranium. He highlighted the form of the figurine at right (Woman Leaning on Her Hands [cat. 9]) to suggest a directional light from that side, while he deepened the background tones around the huddled statuette at left (Matisse’s Thorn Extractor [cat. 10]), enveloping it in shade. He used shadows to link other objects on the table to one another. In the terracotta pot Matisse manipulated the paint after it had been applied—wiping back, scraping with a knife, and dry brushing to expose the underlying colors to lend the pot a more worn appearance.

The multilayer interactive image viewer is designed to facilitate the viewer’s exploration and comparison of the technical images (fig. 11.1).

Signed: Henri-Matisse (lower left, in dilute blue paint) (fig. 11.2 and fig. 11.3). The signature was added over dry paint but before a final layer of green was applied to the tabletop, which overlaps it slightly.

Flax (commonly known as linen).

The original dimensions of the canvas were 100 × 81 cm. This corresponds to a no. 40 portrait (figure) standard-size (100 × 73 cm) canvas.

Plain weave. Medium weight. Average thread count (standard deviation): 12.5V (0.2) × 16.5H (0.9) threads/cm. The vertical threads were determined to correspond to the warp and the horizontal threads to the weft.

The threads are quite thin and somewhat loosely woven. Thread-density maps indicate mild cusping on all four sides, probably the result of stretching onto the original stretcher. The lack of strong cusping at any particular edge suggests that Still Life with Geranium was not cut near an edge of the larger pre-primed canvas piece but instead was cut somewhere in the middle.

Current stretching: Dates to the 1951 lining (see Conservation History). The current dimensions are slightly larger than in the original stretching—0.3 cm in the vertical direction and 0.5 cm in the horizontal direction—due to keying out of the stretcher.

Original stretching: The placement of the original tacks could not be observed because the edges are covered by paper tape.

Current stretcher: The current six-member stretcher may be original to the painting. When the canvas was lined in 1951, the restorer repaired and retained the stretcher (see Conservation History). Dimensions: width, 5.8 cm; depth, 1.5 cm (fig. 11.4).

Original stretcher: See above.

None observed in current examination or documented in previous examinations.

A cross-section shows a brownish organic sizing layer below the ground that has a strong blue fluorescence in ultraviolet light (possibly glue) (fig. 11.5).

Pre-primed with ground layers extending on all four sides. Cross-sectional analysis revealed two layers of ground: the top layer is much thinner (15–55 μm) and the bottom layer is thicker (44–122 μm) (fig. 11.6). The lower layer contains many warm pigment particles, creating a yellowish-beige tone (fig. 11.7). The ground appears to have been applied by large sweeps of a brush, and the brushmarks are sometimes visible on the surface of the painting (fig. 11.8).

Unpainted ground is left exposed around patches of brushwork. Some areas of seemingly exposed ground are in fact covered by glaze. There is more exposed ground around all the table objects, such as the figurines, which lends them a brightness and more immediate presence.

When observed microscopically, the ground appears warm yellowish-white with many small white lumps (fig. 11.9). Although the pigmented particles are primarily in the lower ground, the upper ground is thin and does not mask the warm tone.

FTIR analysis determined the ground to be lead white (basic lead carbonate), barium sulfate, and traces of kaolin in an oil medium. SEM/EDX analysis found that the lower layer is mostly lead white with some barium sulfate, zinc-based white, iron oxide red and orange with associated silicates and traces of ultramarine blue, carbon-based black, silicates, and silica. The top layer is mostly lead white with traces of aluminum silicate, iron oxide, and possibly zinc white.

Infrared examination (0.9–1.7 μm) reveals a rudimentary black painted sketch (fig. 11.10, fig. 11.11). These marks served only as general indications for the placement of elements. Lines to set the position of the terracotta pot, the table edge, and a few geranium stems were not closely followed. The painted sketch lines that loosely indicated the position of the two figurines are still visible under the final contour lines, as are the two different sets of lines for the jug’s handle.

The sketch was executed in a black paint (estimated to be oil).

Matisse made only a few changes as the sketch developed: the shift in the jug handle and the adjustments in the figurines are still visible (fig. 11.12). Infrared examination reveals lines around the figurine at left, suggesting that it originally may have been farther to the left (fig. 11.13). A line for the lower right edge of the terracotta pot lies farther to the right than the painted edge. A sketched leaf to the right of the top flower was not used (fig. 11.14).

Matisse first painted the preliminary sketch, then laid extremely thin glazes of subtle, shifting color over the background area, with a darker color in the top corners. Underneath the top paint layers, a pale-orange tone of the glaze in the upper right shifts to a lightly applied brown, and becomes more yellow below and toward the left (fig. 11.15 and fig. 11.16). With these thin wash-like glazes, the artist created a sense of light and atmosphere for the geranium. Matisse began blocking in the geranium leaves using subtle pale-purple strokes (fig. 11.17). On the right side, he blocked around the edges of these leaves with violet strokes to set the pale plant against a darker background (fig. 11.18). He then reworked the leaves in green, painting them with direct brushy patches, using a range of unmodulated shades of green, from dark olive to yellow-green. The leaves only loosely follow the pale purple lay-in, which only loosely followed the sketch. More leaves were then added to fill in the plant. The artist applied additional layers of paint to some leaves, making them more opaque, changing the color, or enlivening them with yellow highlights, pink flowers, and red buds, most often working quickly and wet-in-wet (fig. 11.19).

In the top corners, Matisse painted white to lighten the initial orange and brown glazes and enclosing penumbra with bright light from above. To reintegrate these white patches, he added fluid strokes of blue (left) and turquoise (right), which are thin enough that the luminosity of the white is still visible (fig. 11.20 and fig. 11.21). He filled in around the plant with different blues, layering and blending them in some areas to bring the tones closer together and soften their brushwork (fig. 11.22). Thus, the blues have been worked to lessen their contrast, while the geranium leaves stand out because of their contrast and variety. The artist gave the blue atmosphere around the plant a sense of depth, as the lighter blues seem to envelop the geranium from the front and the dark blues from behind, so that space and form interpenetrate. This process exemplifies the subtlety of Matisse’s adjustments. In the lower background Matisse made color changes that suggest a directional light from the right. He blocked out the previous violet, brown, yellow and green glazes with very pale pink and blue scumbles (fig. 11.23). He reinforced the sense of light on this side by adding strokes of strong highlight and shadow on the arms of the figurine at right (fig. 11.24). Conversely, Matisse darkened the blocks of violet, pale purple, and pink surrounding the figurine at left (fig. 11.25).

The tabletop was laid in with a variety of washes in earthy shades of green, brown, purple, and pink, shifting from darker and more opaque in the back to transparently brighter toward the front and right. The objects on the table were laced together with dark shadows, while occasional pale-highlight strokes separate the forms.

In some areas, Matisse manipulated the paint after it had been applied with various tools. Wiping, dry brushing, scraping, and gouging were used on the geranium pot, which lend the surface the worn, moldy, porous appearance of aged terracotta (fig. 11.26). This container was first laid in with brown, dark green, and olive green. Before the greens had dried, the artist painted over them with varied pinks, and while still wet, the pink of the pot’s middle section was dry brushed, which lightly removed the wet paint in visible strokes to reveal the green below (fig. 11.27). The pink on the left side has been lightly wiped, exposing the tops of the wrinkled olive-green paint underneath (fig. 11.28). On the right side there is a V-shaped gouge through the wet paint, and the surface appears lightly scraped (fig. 11.29).

Brushes, primarily medium width. Various tools and techniques were used to manipulate the paint surface: wiping (probably with a cloth), dry brushing, scraping, and gouging (probably with a palette knife).

Purples, pinks, reds, and violets played a stronger role in the earlier stages of the painting process, and blues and additional greens during the later stages. Matisse made many color changes (see Paint Layer). Eventually Matisse used all the primary and secondary colors in varied tones and tints: green, blue, red, orange, purple, and yellow (in descending order), as well as brown, black, and white. Dilute glazes of pale orange, yellow, brown, pink, lavender, blue, and turquoise were also used.

Oil (estimated). Matisse added extra medium for areas of very fluid paint, as in the small geranium sprout (fig. 11.30).The thin shadow below the left onion appears highly diluted with turpentine (fig. 11.31). The fluidity and thinness of the blue paint covering the white scumbles in the top corners suggests that the paint contained a large amount of both medium and turpentine.

The painting is presently unvarnished. A natural-resin varnish was applied at an unknown date and was removed in 2008. This varnish was not original. Both abrasion of the paint in some spots and a very heavy layer of grime underneath the varnish indicate that the picture probably remained unvarnished for some time after it was painted.

Acquired in 1932, the earliest treatment recorded in the conservation object file is from February 1951, when the painting was cleaned and lined with an aqueous adhesive, and the stretcher repaired, by an outside conservator. Paste or glue remnants from a facing were found on top of the natural-resin varnish, suggesting that it was cleaned and revarnished before it was lined. This cleaning, or a previous one, caused abrasion to the thin paint and glaze layers, particularly on the tops of the threads, leaving mottled, grime-covered paint in the interstices. This abrasion occurred in a large area of the top right corner and down the right side of the background. Some losses, primarily along the top and right edges, had been retouched before the varnish was applied but had become ill matched. The tension of the facing adhesive layer on the varnish surface caused numerous areas of fragile lifting paint and tiny paint losses as the adhesive contracted.

In 2005, the lifting paint was consolidated, and the facing adhesive residue on the surface was removed.

In 2008, the picture was cleaned, removing the yellowed natural-resin varnish, discolored repaint, and the underlying grime. Losses and the abrasion occurring during the earlier treatment were filled and retouched. The surface was not revarnished.

The painting is in good condition, except where the top paint and glaze layers were partially abraded in an earlier treatment in the top right corner (extending down almost to the leaves) and along the right edge of the background. These areas have now been inpainted to recover the artist’s brushwork and tonalities, matching the colors still present in the interstices, between the abraded highpoints, as a guide. The aqueous lining has not significantly affected the appearance of the painting. The paint and ground layer remain very fragile and generally are not well adhered to the canvas. There have been numerous pinhole-size losses (fig. 11.32). Lifting paint on a microscopic scale is a recurring problem requiring consolidation.  
Kristin Hoermann Lister, with contributions by Inge Fiedler

Current frame (installed 2009): The frame is not original to the painting. It is an American, twenty-first-century, gilt, molding frame with an ovolo face. The pine molding has oil gilding with a pigmented glue size, applied over flat black oil paint on the dark-brown-stained pine. The molding, from the perimeter to the interior, is straight outer side and ovolo (fig. 11.33).

Previous frame (installed 1991; removed 2009): The painting was previously housed in an American (New York), twentieth-century reproduction of a Spanish Baroque, seventeenth-century, architrave frame gilded with stylized [glossary:c-scroll] foliate [glossary:cartouches]. The frame had water gilding on red bole over gesso with a toned varnish layer. The jelutong moldings were carved and mitered and nailed at the corner miters to a basswood back frame glued and nailed to the verso. The molding, from the perimeter to the interior, was ovolo with bead; scotia with stylized c-scroll foliate cartouches at the miter; and torus with ovulos rodeaos (egg surrounds) at the sight edge (fig. 11.34).

Previous frame (installed by 1950; removed at an unknown date): The painting was previously housed in a gilded scotia molding frame with an [glossasry:ogee] sight molding (fig. 11.35).  
Kirk Vuillemot

Westinghouse X-ray unit, film scanned on Epson Expressions 10000XL flatbed scanner. Scans were digitally composited by Robert G. Erdmann, Rijksmuseum, Amsterdam; University of Amsterdam; and Radboud University, Nijmegen.

Goodrich/Sensors Unlimited SU640SDV-1.7RT without filter (0.9–1.7 μm).

Fujifilm S5 Pro with X-Nite 1000B/2 mm filter (1.0–1.1 µm).

Normal-light, raking-light, and transmitted-light overalls and macrophotography: Fujifilm S5 Pro with X-NiteCC1 filter.

Fujifilm S5 Pro with X-NiteCC1 filter and Kodak Wratten 2E filter.

Sinar rePro with 86H digital back; PECA 918 UV/IR interference cut filter and B+W F-PRO filter.

Sample and cross-sectional analysis were performed using a Zeiss Axioplan2 research microscope equipped with reflected light/[glossary:UV fluorescence] and a Zeiss AxioCam MRc5 digital camera. Types of illumination used: darkfield, differential interference contrast (DIC), and ultraviolet. In situ photomicrographs with a Wild Heerbrugg M7A StereoZoom microscope fitted with an Olympus DP71 microscope digital camera.

Zeiss Universal research microscope.

Cross sections were analyzed after carbon coating with a Hitachi S-3400N-II VPSEM with an Oxford energy-dispersive spectrometer (EDS) and a Hitachi solid-state backscattered electron BSE detector. Analysis was performed at the Atomic and Nanoscale Characterization Experimental (NUANCE) Center, Electron Probe Instrumentation Center (EPIC) facility, Northwestern University, Evanston, Illinois.

The samples were mounted on a Specac diamond compression cell for analysis by MFTIR. Data were collected in transmission mode between 4000–400 cm<sup>-1 </sup>at 4cm<sup>-1</sup> resolution and 128 scans per spectrum using a Bruker Hyperion microscope, interfaced to a Tensor 27 spectrometer bench.

Thread count and weave information were determined by Thread Count Automation Project software.

Overlay images registered using an image-based algorithm developed by Damon M. Conover (GW), Dr. John K. Delaney (GW, NGA), and Murray H. Loew (GW) of the George Washington University’s School of Engineering and Applied Science and the National Gallery of Art, Washington, DC.

The image inventory compiles records of all known images of the artwork on file in the Department of Conservation and Science, the Department of Imaging, and the Department of Modern and Contemporary Art at the Art Institute of Chicago (fig. 11.61).

Using the toolbar at the bottom right, any two images of the painting may be selected for comparison by clicking the layers icon to the right of the slider bar. The slider bar may be moved to transition back and forth between the two chosen images. The jagged-line icon brings up a list of available annotations, or colored lines that show the significant features visible in each image, which may be turned on or off in any combination. For example, the red annotation lines, associated with the natural-light image, trace some of the painting’s key compositional features. When overlaid onto a technical image (X-ray, raking light, UV, etc.), the red outlines help the viewer to better observe how features in the technical image relate to or diverge from the painting as seen with the naked eye. (When annotations are turned on, a legend appears in the upper right showing each color and its associated image type.) The circular-arrow icon returns the image to the default settings (natural light, full-image view, natural-light [red] annotation on). The four-arrow icon toggles between the view of the image in the page and a full-screen view of the image. In the upper right corner, the vertical slider bar may be moved to zoom into or out of the image; different parts of the image can be accessed by clicking and dragging within the image itself. The icon in the upper left corner opens a small view of the full image, within which a red box indicates the portion of the overall image being viewed when zooming is enabled.

Stilleben was lent by Oskar Moll, who had recently acquired The Geranium a few months before the exhibition’s opening. A relationship between the two paintings is further suggested by the writings of Roland Schacht (1922), who recalls a still life with a geranium by Matisse at Cassirer in the artist’s “ersten Ausstellung in Deutschland” (pp. 11, 15). However, it is unclear whether Schacht is referring to the appearance of Geranium in this solo exhibition or the group show that occurred Sept. 30–Oct. 18, 1907. A connection between Schacht’s writing, this painting, and the 1909 exhibition was first suggested in Bernhard Echte and Walter Feilchenfeldt’s Kunstsalon Paul Cassiere: Die Ausstellungen 1908–1910 (2013), where the relevant excerpt of Schacht’s text has been reproduced next to an image of The Geranium and included with documentation related to the 1909 exhibition.
